I'm giving this game a thumbs up because of the herculean effort put in by Zenimax to bring the continent of Tamriel to life. As a long-time fan of the Elder Scrolls series, it's really satisfying to see so much of the map available to explore. And the content is, overall, high-quality too.

That said, I have stopped playing this game. ESO asks a lot from you as a player, both in terms of money and time. On the price side of things, it is a full priced game [i]and[/i] it has a(n optional) subscription [i]and[/i] it has numerous full-sized DLCs [i]and[/i] it has microtransactions [i]and[/i] it has lootboxes. It adds up.

Though, for once, it's difficult to say the expenses aren't justified considering the sheer amount of content ESO has. And that's where the time issue comes in. This may be the only game I've ever played that feels like it has [i]too[/i] much content. And it's real content, too, not proc-gen stuff (though there are repeatables). I got into ESO while unemployed, and I [i]still[/i] didn't feel like I had enough time for it. It was very easy to get caught up in just doing daily quests (of which there are hundreds), and never have time to do anything else (like play the story quests, or roleplay, or PVP, or).

The gameplay itself is solid. The combat's nothing to write home about, but that's normal for an MMO. The writing makes an effort to actually be good, and a lot of the time it succeeds. Overall the game has a steady, deliberate pace that might feel subdued if you're expecting Skyrim-style hijinks, but works well if you have the patience to take your time and explore. The artstyle is mixed, with some of the older zones looking distinctly unpolished compared to some truly stunning design in the more recent content. And of course the music slaps.

ESO is the game to play if you have both money and a lot of time to spare, and you like the idea of this being your main game. You can get lost in it, for better and for worse. For me, it was a bit too much.

This is basically the most solo mmo in existence. If not THE most, then easily top 3. Next to GW2 and SWTOR. If you've ever wanted to play a single-player Elder Scrolls with optional multiplayer that's constantly being updated, ESO is it. 

Can't say I'm a fan of their monetization. Buy to play, sub and now the new content passes not included as a part of the sub? Not great. Or how the crafting bag exemplifies creating a problem only to solve it through money (sub). But if you time your purchases and don't care about playing the newest content right when it drops then it doesn't matter. There's been over a decade of stuff added to this title which makes immediate access to brand new content irrelevant for newcomers. As for timing purchases, wait for a big sale (like Christmas, Thanksgiving or anniversary) to grab the large chapter bundles that come out yearly or so. Plus, sub for like 6 months and sit on your Crown allotment, then buy expansion content through the crown store when it goes on deep sale. You can then play without sub for a long time.

But you know, if you see the subscription as simply part of the service, it's really not so bad. FFXIV is B2P and sub, yet no one ever complains about that. The only reason Zenimax gets heat for this is because of how aggressive their monetization is. People don't like being maneuvered to do things, and not having everything included in the sub price now is just a bad idea. That said, the overall business model is pretty much the same. Minus the content pass which hopefully doesn't become an ongoing thing. 

There's some excellent writing, humor, and tons of fantasy lore the likes of which only Elder Scrolls can deliver. Also a surprising amount of 'gray' choices. While I enjoy the usual trappings of mmo grind same as anyone else, the conflicting morality behind much of the story is a big part of the draw. It's excellent.

This review is from a player with years of gameplay written for new potential players, mostly.  Elder Scrolls Online is a terrific game.  Leveling your character, exploring new environments, doing quests while getting stronger and receiving reward is very enjoyable.  In it's base form, there are different classes to test out with unique skill lines and unique abilities.  There are different weapon skill lines with their own unique abilities.  You can play your character(s) with a focus and specialization of dealing damage, or play with a focus on the ability to heal others while contributing some damage, or perhaps specialize your build to draw and hold the attention of enemies as a bulwark while players you are grouped with are left free to bring dungeon bosses down.  In this way, ESO is similar to other multi-player games available.  There are very easy dungeons to run where you can learn your role and have plenty of room to make mistakes.  As you master skills and get comfortable there are progressively more difficult options, such as veteran dungeons and trials that test your more - with better reward.

To me, the above is reason enough to try the game.  The other aspect of the game which has been very enjoyable for me is the player-vs-player battlegrounds and the alliance wars.  Honestly, this is the most challenging and evolving activity in the game.  In its current state, ESO PvP needs work.  I have over 3600 hours of gameplay, experiencing many different adjustments to the game through changes in classes, armor sets, mythic gear used in PvP, and the present state has the most unbalanced PvP I have seen in years.  Some players having the benefit of time, practice, resources and knowledge have made devastating builds that can kill you in an instant and turn into an unkillable tank in the next instant.  Even for me it is incredibly frustrating (and I am no means an expert at PvP).  I know the gear these players are using, I know the combination of skills they are using and in what order, and I know why most players are following the same setup:  if you stray too far from the Best setup (the "meta"), you simply cannot compete at a level where you can stand toe-to-toe with your opponent.  That being said, I enjoy trying different setups and avoiding the "meta" that so many are comfortable relying upon.  I seems lazy and unfulfilling to copy some influencer's recommendations after playing so long.  For a new player, however, I highly suggest following their recommendations.  Remember, even with sub-standard gear and a unique setup you can find a style of play that is enjoyable and you can contribute to the success of your team as you wage battle against other players.

To players who have many hours of gameplay and are thinking about revisiting the game, the development of sub-classing and the adoption of the scribing system into base game make the time spent back in the game worthwhile.  I do not recommend the yearly pass.  The Monomyth Reforged mythic is strong, but it's no better than Oakensoul for more casual play and it's no better than Markyn's or Death Dealer's Fete - you simply save a skill slot on your bar.  I have Monomyth on two character builds and it is powerful, but not worth the money and the changes coming up might nerf the benefits seen.  The amount of unkillable players in PvP is very high and many players seem to not understand they should be ignored and weaker more threatening players should be targeted.  It is frustrating.

All in all, I still love the game.  I 100% recommend exploring purchasing ESO and exploring Tamriel !  Thanks for reading!

The Elder Scrolls¬Æ Online (ESO), developed by ZeniMax Online Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks, is a massively multiplayer online role-playing game set in the Elder Scrolls universe. It transforms the single-player experience of Skyrim and Oblivion into a shared world spanning nearly all of Tamriel. Over the years, it has evolved into one of the most complete and accessible MMOs available.

Gameplay combines traditional Elder Scrolls exploration with MMO structure. Players create a character from multiple races and factions, then explore the world completing quests, dungeons, and world events. The combat system is action-oriented‚Äîaiming, blocking, dodging, and timing attacks matter more than statistics alone, keeping it closer to the single-player series than most MMOs.

The game‚Äôs structure supports both solo and cooperative play. Story quests are fully voiced, offering depth and player choice, while group content such as dungeons, trials, and world bosses provides long-term challenges. The balance between narrative immersion and multiplayer systems is one of ESO‚Äôs strongest features.

Visually, ESO captures the variety of Tamriel with large, detailed zones ranging from volcanic islands to snowy peaks and ancient cities. The art direction emphasizes consistency with Elder Scrolls lore, while lighting and weather systems give each region distinct atmosphere. Performance remains stable even in large-scale PvP battles.

The soundtrack and sound design uphold the series‚Äô reputation for quality. Jeremy Soule‚Äôs early contributions and later expansions‚Äô music maintain the epic tone. Ambient effects‚Äîwind, wildlife, city chatter‚Äîadd authenticity. Full voice acting for every quest NPC strengthens immersion.

Regular expansions and updates continue to expand content and refine mechanics. Chapters like Morrowind, Summerset, and High Isle each introduce new regions, systems, and stories without fragmenting the community. The flexible leveling system allows new players to explore any zone regardless of progression, making ESO remarkably beginner-friendly.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls¬Æ Online stands as one of the most refined and content-rich MMORPGs today. It offers a deep narrative, strong combat, and constant updates within a cohesive world. For both longtime Elder Scrolls fans and MMO players seeking an immersive, story-driven experience, ESO delivers lasting value and consistent evolution.

üé≠ Story & Quests

ESO‚Äôs quests are genuinely impressive. Every single one is fully voice acted, and the writing has real depth. Characters have personality, regional accents, and moral complexity, it feels like you‚Äôre playing a single-player Elder Scrolls story inside an MMO world. Each zone tells its own tale, and exploring them is consistently rewarding rather than repetitive.

‚öîÔ∏è Combat

Combat is responsive but not for everyone. It uses an action-based system where you manually aim attacks rather than using tab-targeting. Personally, I find this frustrating, I prefer being able to lock onto targets. Still, once you get used to it, it‚Äôs fluid and skill-based, and the healing built into some abilities (like the Templar‚Äôs Puncturing Sweep) makes it surprisingly tactical.

üõ†Ô∏è Progression & Builds

Character progression is incredibly deep. You can mix weapon, class, guild, and crafting skills to create almost any build imaginable. The downside is that it‚Äôs overwhelming at first. The Champion Point system extends progression far beyond level 50, but figuring out what‚Äôs worth investing in takes patience and research. Once it clicks, though, it‚Äôs very satisfying, there‚Äôs always a new layer to refine.

‚öíÔ∏è Crafting, Gathering & Economy

I love ESO‚Äôs crafting system. Every resource you gather has a purpose, even ‚Äújunk‚Äù can be deconstructed for materials to craft or sell. It makes looting feel meaningful.
Trading, however, is divisive. You can‚Äôt simply open a global market; you have to join trading guilds and travel to their vendors to buy or sell. It‚Äôs immersive and realistic, but inconvenient if you prefer quick, centralised trading.

Inventory management can also be rough. Some useful consumables you receive can‚Äôt be stored in your bank, so storage fills quickly. Players like me who hoard everything will find this especially frustrating.

üè∞ Dungeons & Group Content

Dungeons are atmospheric and well-designed, but can be confusing when you‚Äôre new. Experienced players often sprint through, leaving you struggling to keep up or understand the mechanics. Despite that, bosses are creative, and the combat flow in group play is smooth once you learn the ropes.

‚è≥ Time-Gated Systems

Researching traits for crafting takes real-world hours, and upgrading your mount‚Äôs speed, stamina, or capacity is limited to one upgrade per day. These systems give a sense of long-term progress, but they can feel punishing when you‚Äôre just starting out.

üåç World, Visuals & Performance

The world is beautiful, sprawling landscapes, detailed cities, and excellent lighting even on older hardware. The music is wonderful and fits each region perfectly. The game runs smoothly now; I used to have issues with NPCs not spawning properly, but switching to fibre broadband fixed that completely.

üßëü§ùüßë Community & Social Experience

ESO has a huge community, but how social your experience is depends on you. I rarely interact in guilds, so most of my communication happens in dungeons, usually when someone asks for a specific drop or when things go wrong mid-fight. The community in general seems friendly and mature, but it‚Äôs easy to play almost entirely solo if you prefer. Maybe there's a very social side I'm missing.

üí¨ Overall Impression

Even with its flaws, ESO is a fantastic MMO. It‚Äôs easy to sink hundreds of hours into exploring, crafting, and questing. The amount of content is staggering, and the storytelling easily surpasses most online games. I'd consider myself a newbie, yet I have over 400 hours.

The game can feel overwhelming at first, and a few systems are unnecessarily restrictive, but once you take the time to understand how everything fits together, it becomes one of the most rewarding experiences in the genre.

The "Play Your Way" Promise Delivered

After spending over 1000 hours in Tamriel, the singular thing that keeps me coming back to The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) is freedom. Most MMORPGs lock you into a rigid box, you are a Healer, or you are a Tank, and that is all you will ever be.

ESO destroys that box.

I play a High Elf Warden who functions as a thief, an assassin, and a mage all at once. The "Armory" system and the sheer number of skill lines, from Guilds like the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves Guild to weapon skills like Dual Wield and Destruction Staff, allow for a level of customization that is staggering. You want to be a nature-magic wielding assassin who heals? You can do that. You want to be a heavy-armored tank who uses lightning magic? You can do that too.

A Thief's Paradise

One of the most underrated aspects of ESO is the Justice System. Unlike other MMOs where NPCs are just static quest givers, in ESO, almost every NPC has pockets to pick and a house to rob.

The Thieves Guild and Dark Brotherhood DLCs are standout experiences. Sneaking through heavily guarded manors, managing your "Heat" and "Bounty," and executing perfect heists offers a stealth game experience that rivals single-player titles like Thief or Dishonored, all within an MMO environment.

Lore that Matters

For those who love story, this game is a bottomless well. The quests aren't just "kill 10 rats." They are fully voiced, complex narratives involving political intrigue, Daedric Princes, and ancient history.

As a High Elf player, exploring the pristine, slightly xenophobic beauty of Summerset Isle feels vastly different than crawling through the swamps of Black Marsh. The game respects the player's intelligence and rewards you for paying attention to the history and culture of the races.

The "Grandpa" Factor (Accessibility)

As an older gamer with a busy life, ESO respects my time.

Solo Friendly: You can play 90% of the content (overland quests, delves, public dungeons) entirely solo.

Horizontal Progression: The gear cap hasn't increased in years. If you take a six-month break to be with family, your gear is still relevant when you come back. You don't get punished for having a life outside the game.

The Verdict

Elder Scrolls Online isn't just a game you play to beat; it's a world you live in. Whether you are min-maxing a DPS build for trials or spending your Friday night picking pockets in Abah's Landing, the game offers a richness that few others can match.

Pros:

Incredible build variety and freedom.

Fully voiced, immersive quests.

Best-in-class stealth and justice system.

Respects player time (no gear treadmill).

Cons:

Combat animation cancelling (weaving) can be tricky for new players to master.

The sheer amount of content can be overwhelming at first.

Final Thought: If you love fantasy worlds where your character's backstory is just as important as their stats, play this game.

Anyways, this is by far the best online game I have played. It takes the best aspects of MMOs, crafting, PVP, solo PVE, economy, raiding, etc, and changes the worst aspect of MMOs, the combat, to make it as good as it can really be. There is no global cooldown, there arent 50 abilities to track cooldowns, you simply have two ability bars, resource management, and rotation. 

Gathering and crafting is as well implemented and addictive as any game. The way it is executed adds to the experience as well. Take for example the placement of crafting nodes. The beginner zones and the end zones have the highest concentration of crafting nodes. This gives experienced players reason to hang out in the beginner zones which gives newer players and new characters a better experience. It also helps players focus on the main story in the middle zones, which believe it or not the zone quests or story quests are effing amazing if you are into Elder Scrolls lore. This game takes place before all of the single player games, and gives a back story to every corner of the game's planet. Seriously, I challenge you to find a fan of the actual lore who doesn't like how this game's story fills in the gaps. Once you get a hang of combat the zone quests or "overland" content can feel really easy and you find yourself rushing through it to get the skill points rewarded for completing main stories, but this isn't even the focus of the game. The story is simply something to do while waiting for friends or if you want to take a break from anything else, or progress your character by gaining easy experience and skill points, or if you just want to be forced to explore corners of the map. 

The maps are absolutely incredible. Even the base game maps. If you pay attention and read the notes and books scattered about you realize how much love the developers put into these 100% handcrafted zones. One of my greatest experiences in this game was playing some random quest in Deshaan (Morrowind mainland) and finding a bunch of pieces of paper scattered around to read. It turned out to be some story that was obviously a serious real life thing from one of the dev's lives they put into the game. It made sense for where I was and what i was doing, but it was so real at the same time I connected with some tech nerd i have never met. 

The group PVE is the best part of this game, unless you prefer PVP which is also fantastic. There are tons of dungeons, each from recognizable places from the single player games, places you have read about in random books, or places you have heard about from NPC dialogue. They always have their own story and fun bits of lore. I played WOW for a bit and the dungeons are, kill these guys, collect these items. ESO takes them to another planet compared to other MMOs. The normal difficulty is easy enough, challenging enough for newer players. The "veteran" difficulty makes them an actual challenge to complete normally forcing you to follow mechanics for boss fights, then the "hard mode" makes it actually hard. The greatest experiences you can have in this game is finding a group to tackle the hard mode challenges together. I am not joking when you are newer to the game you think it is absolutely impossible to complete dungeons on just plain veteran mode, but then you progress and learn mechanics as a group with each player being responsible for something so important you feel like you are the reason you completed the challenge. Seriously some of the fights are so hard you will spend years trying to complete them on the hardest difficulty, and when you finally complete it you win a title and wear it proudly for months. I still remember random players in voice chat saying "dope Alpha Predator title". It sounds really cool and was proof to everybody on the server I completed something that was very difficult to do at the time. There are also 12 player raids which take the 4 man dungeon idea and takes it to a higher level, where on the higher difficulties it requires every participant to be on point 100% of the time with the mechanics. Personally I have more fun with the 4 man dungeons, being more personal and the fact that most people who are attracted to MMOs don't like me personally, making it tougher to be a part of the "cool" crowd and get the hard mode raids. It is not difficult to find guilds and groups that will bring you on to their teams. 

The PVP is also fantastic. I mean every aspect of this game is great. You can queue for smaller group deathmatch and other CTF type games, which are great and require specific builds just for these games, or you can travel into the center of the map where there are server wide faction wars with epic battles of hundreds of players happening 24/7. I have spent 20+ hours straight in Cyrodil because it is just that fun! There is a ton of PVE things to do here as well, but it is constant PVP with three warring factions fighting for control of the map. Overtaking castles and outposts changes fast travel dynamics and supply lines. The thing about PVP is that it allows for completely different builds and strategies. The set bonuses from gear required to do the hardest veteran hard mode raids in the game will leave you to be absolutely destroyed by one single player in PVP. That being said, the builds required to excel in PVP will make you borderline useless in end game PVE. It is so well implemented as it allows you to completely rethink the entire game when exploring different aspects of gameplay. Most people play through a ton of PVE content and know what works and what is useless against the mobs. But when you start to dabble in PVP after getting burned out on PVE you realize every one of those "useless" skills works exactly as described against players and makes every single build viable, especially when you are in a group of 50+ players and you can add something special to the group. Also worth mentioning that the "meta" builds for PVP are often acquired by completing challenging PVE content, and visa versa. I cannot express enough how well the different game modes coinside with each other. 

You can even skip combat completely and spend countless hours gathering, crafting, and helping people build houses. The wealthiest players in the game are those who specialized certain crafting skills and can build and sell extremely rare and valuable furnishings. I cannot touch too much on this because I spent my time doing combat and exploration, but there is a TON of content for crafters, fashion and housing enthusiasts.

I will cut this rambling review short because I have to go into job on short notice, but if you are looking for an extremely deep elder scrolls experience you can share with hundreds of friends, you must give this a try. If you are bored, try different playstyles. If you just want to be a jerk go to Valkel Guard and run your mouth in area chat and fight other players. I promise there is something for every player in this game. If not there is always Call of Duty i guess.

TL;DR - Recent updates have ruined the game, content pass seems scummy, ESO+ is okay in my eyes, player base is/has declined dramtically, AI ban waves are falsely banning accounts new and old. 

For the casual/new players this game is great. There's a lot to learn but it isn't as technical or difficult as other MMOs. However for long time players it's become a joke - the last few updates especially. Crazy changes to the skill/bar system leave you running back and forth between skills and set ups while wondering if the build you're using will even be valid next month, it just doesn't seem to respect your time anymore. 

Next biggest issue is the AI ban waves - so many people have been banned unjustly due to the AI moderation system they seem to be using. Trying to appeal it is a joke and some players with hundreds of dollars spent and thousands of hours invested have permanently lost their accounts for no real reason. Even fresh level 10-20 players have been banned out of no where for no reason..

Then there's the content pass, up until this year (2025) ESO released 1 main expansion you could purchase and you'd get a complete expansion pack for the game. New zone, new zone quests, new items, furnishings etc etc. Now they've decided to make you pay extra to drip feed you 1 expansion throughout the whole year, essentially making you pay full price for something you won't have access to for months, half a year even.

The ESO+ system is subjective - I felt the pricing is fair enough considering what you gain from it (all expansions except the very newest one, unlimited crafting mat storage, 10% xp bonus and 1650 crowns per month). The player base - the people are amazing here, you can make real and long term friendships with the people you meet. That's not exclusive to ESO though. The real issue with player base is the declining numbers, you can find rough numbers by googling but keep in mind those numbers are divided between US and EU servers.
